newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: ILO head upbeat on S.African labour relations.
newsitem.headline: ILO head upbeat on S.African labour relations.

text.p: International Labour Organisation (ILO) Director-General Michel Hansenne said on Thursday he saw encouraging signs of consensus emerging between South African labour, business and government.

"There are a lot of challenges, but what struck me is that after two years (of democracy) I have the impression that South Africa has been able to build the tools to meet the challenge," he told reporters at the end of a four-day visit.

"What is important is that through Nedlac (National Economic Development and Labour Council), through the other institutions over the last two years, it is possible for the South African society to find good solutions."
Nedlac was established to bring together government, business and trade unions in post-apartheid South Africa.

The Geneva-based ILO issued a major report on South Africa last year supporting a macro-economic strategy based on managed trade liberalisation, backed by a state-supported, selective industrial strategy and a negotiated employment-incomes policy.

South Africa emerged from the apartheid era with a legacy of extreme income inequality and chronically high unemployment. But the ILO report argued that existing market information underestimated employment and overstated unemployment, which is officiallly pegged at around a third of the workforce.
